videos.headline: Teske delivers bucket through contact
videos.description: Jon Teske goes up for the alley-oop layup and gets fouled as he hits the bucket for Michigan.

videos.headline: Livers delivers wide-open corner 3
videos.description: Isaiah Livers drops a 3-pointer for Michigan in the corner late in the first half against South Carolina.

videos.headline: Bryant throws down monster dunk
videos.description: South Carolina's Keyshawn Bryant throws down a massive two-handed slam dunk in the second half vs. Michigan.

article.description: Jordan Poole scored 19 of his 26 points in the second half, and No. 5 Michigan remained unbeaten with an 89-78 victory over South Carolina on Saturday.

video.headline: Matthews hits wide-open 3
video.caption: Charles Matthews hits a wide-open 3-pointer as Michigan goes up by 8 over South Carolina.
video.description: Charles Matthews hits a wide-open 3-pointer as Michigan goes up by 8 over South Carolina.
video.title: Matthews hits wide-open 3

article.headline: No. 5 Michigan stays unbeaten, tops South Carolina 89-78

images.name: Matthews hits wide-open 3
images.caption: Charles Matthews hits a wide-open 3-pointer as Michigan goes up by 8 over South Carolina.

article.linkText: No. 5 Michigan stays unbeaten, tops South Carolina 89-78
article.story: ANN ARBOR, Mich. -- South Carolina coach Frank Martin had a simple explanation for why Michigan's Jordan Poole is so tough to defend. "He makes the easy shots, and he makes the hard shots," Martin said. Poole scored 19 of his 26 points in the second half, and No. 5 Michigan remained unbeaten with an 89-78 victory over South Carolina on Saturday. The Gamecocks scored more points than any team all season against Michigan, but the Wolverines were ahead by six at halftime, and they led comfortably for most of the second half. Iggy Brazdeikis scored 17 points and Jon Teske added 15 for Michigan. Chris Silva led South Carolina with 18. The Wolverines have won 24 of their last 25 games, with the lone defeat coming in the national title game against Villanova last season. "We knew coming into the year that we'd have a target on our backs simply because of what we did last year, but we're just taking it day by day, we're locked in at practice, we prepare for the game plan," Poole said. "The coaches do a really good job of keeping us in the moment." Michigan was coming off its first close game of the season -- a two-point win at Northwestern on Tuesday night. The Wolverines were uncharacteristically careless against South Carolina (4-5), turning the ball over 11 times in the first half and 16 in the game. Still, Michigan (10-0) went on a 13-2 run near the end of the first and led 42-36 at halftime. Poole went to work in the second half with a pair of 3-pointers and a dunk, putting the Wolverines up 56-45. The sophomore guard scored 15 points in the first 10 minutes of the half. "I just feel like I was letting the game come to me, pretty much, but also being aggressive," Poole said. "I wasn't being aggressive earlier on in the season, I don't think." BALANCE Teske had nine rebounds and three blocks. He and Poole are sometimes overshadowed offensively by Brazdeikis and Charles Matthews, but not on this day. "I love what Jon and Jordan are doing right now," coach John Beilein said. "They're as key as any of the guys that are getting any other type of attention." NOT BACKING DOWN Despite the presence of the 7-foot-1 Teske, South Carolina outscored Michigan 44-26 in the paint. Silva said the key is sticking with the offensive plan all the way through each possession. "Today we took the time, we grew up, we tried to execute to the end," Silva said. BIG PICTURE South Carolina: No opponent had shot better than 45 percent from the field against Michigan. The Gamecocks finished at 52 and also won the turnover battle against the Wolverines. South Carolina was done in by fouls. Michigan shot 23 of 30 on free throws while the Gamecocks were just 9 of 14. "I saw a different gear from our guys," Martin said. "I was real proud that they stepped up to the challenge of playing such a good team." Michigan: The Wolverines had held every opponent under 40 percent from the floor until their last two games, when Northwestern and South Carolina eclipsed that. So Michigan hasn't been as dominant this week at the defensive end, but the Wolverines had five players score at least 12 points Saturday and won without much drama. POLL IMPLICATIONS Nobody ahead of Michigan lost this week, although Sunday's matchup between No. 1 Gonzaga and No. 7 Tennessee could affect where the Wolverines end up in the next ranking. UP NEXT South Carolina: The Gamecocks take a break for exams before hosting No. 4 Virginia on Dec. 19. Michigan: The Wolverines face their first in-state opponent of the season when they host Western Michigan next Saturday. --- More AP college basketball: https://apnews.com/Collegebasketball and https://twitter.com/AP-Top25 --- Follow Noah Trister at www.Twitter.com/noahtrister

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
